title: 110_hr3678
content: The "Internet Tax Freedom Act Amendments Act of 2007" changes the moratorium on internet taxes to extend until 2014. States that currently tax internet access are grandfathered in. The Internet Tax Freedom Act Amendments Act of 2007 extends the moratorium on internet taxes until 2014. Section 1104 of the Act defines 'Internet access' for taxation purposes, with exceptions until June 30, 2008. The Internet Tax Freedom Act Amendments Act of 2007 extends the moratorium on internet taxes until 2014. It states that no inference of legislative construction shall be drawn from the subsection or amendments made by the Act for any period prior to June 30, 2008, with respect to any tax subject to specific exceptions related to telecommunications services. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. Section 1105 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to define "Internet access" as a service that enables users to connect to the Internet and includes telecommunications purchased, used, or sold to provide such service. It also includes incidental services like home pages, email, and instant messaging. The Internet Tax Freedom Act defines "Internet access" as a service enabling connection to the Internet, including telecommunications and incidental services like home pages, email, and instant messaging. Telecommunications are defined as per the Communications Act of 1934. The Internet Tax Freedom Act defines "Internet access" as a service enabling connection to the Internet, including telecommunications services as defined in the Communications Act of 1934. The term "tax on Internet access" does not include certain State taxes on commercial activity, gross receipts, taxable margin, or gross income of businesses. The Internet Tax Freedom Act specifies criteria for taxes imposed on business activities, ensuring they are non-discriminatory and broad in scope, replacing certain types of taxes. The Internet Tax Freedom Act allows states to modify taxes on business activities after November 1, 2007, as long as the changes do not significantly limit the scope of the tax. No implications should be drawn from this provision for taxes prior to November 1, 2007. SEC. 5 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act amends accounting rules for telecommunications services to include enabling users to access content over the Internet. It also removes section 1108 related to voice services. SEC. 6 addresses the sunset of grandfather provisions. SEC. 6 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act addresses the sunset of grandfather provisions, stating that certain states are exempt if they have repealed taxes on Internet access more than 24 months prior to the enactment of this provision. SEC. 7 specifies that the Act and its amendments will take effect on November 1, 2007.
